ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

EMISSIONS OF CARBON DIOXIDE PER CAPITA

(Singapore's ranking)


    1. Mr Simon S C Tay asked the Minister for the Environment how Singapore ranks in the emissions of carbon dioxide per capita, in comparison to other countries and what efforts are being made to reduce the emissions.

    The Senior Minister of State for the Environment (Encik Sidek bin Saniff) (for the Minister for the Environment): Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore ranked 24th in the world in terms of per capita carbon dioxide emission in 1995, based on a comparison between our carbon dioxide emission figures and data compiled by a US-based agency. Our per capita emission is lower than countries such as the USA, Canada, Japan, Germany, Denmark, the UK as well as Australia.

    In Singapore, power generation accounts for half of the carbon dioxide emission, and industries and road transportation account for much of the remaining 50%. A wide range of measures taken over the years has helped to keep down carbon dioxide emissions from these sources.

    In power generation, new technology and greater efficiency in generation have meant more electricity being produced from the same unit of fossil fuel. As the use of natural gas in place of fuel oil can reduce carbon dioxide emission by up to 25%, we are planning to use more natural gas for power generation in the future.

    Much effort has also gone into improving energy use efficiency. The Public Works Department has laid down energy conservation standards aimed at promoting energy-saving building designs. The Public Utilities Board conducts regular educational programmes and training courses on energy conservation. It also conducts energy audits to help the industrial and commercial sectors identify oppor-

Column: 1351

tunities for energy efficiency improvements. My Ministry, together with the Ministry of Finance, has introduced a tax incentive scheme to encourage the corporate sector to replace energy-inefficient equipment and to invest in energy-efficient technologies. Thus far, nine companies have benefited from this scheme.

    In the land transport sector, our vehicle ownership policy, in combination with our very energy-efficient public transport system, has moderated fuel consumption by motor vehicles.

    Mr Simon S C Tay (Nominated Member): Sir, given that our Government's figures show a relatively lower emission per capita for Singapore, will our Government take steps to release these figures widely and the efforts we are making, especially to rebut those who believe Singapore emits a much higher figure?

    Encik Sidek bin Saniff: Sir, the Ministry has been liaising with the national agency, which publishes carbon dioxide emission figures, to point out the inaccuracies in the figures for Singapore. We have likewise given the facts to our local media. I am quite sure the Member was referring to World Wide Fund (WWF) for Nature where they put down ours as about 35 tonnes per capita, whereas ours is only 8.2, almost as good as New Zealand. So we have corrected that part by using the standard accepted, ie, IPCC measurement. And IPCC measurement is a measurement recognised and accepted by all.

    Mr Simon Tay: May I ask the Senior Minister of State, if Singapore is supportive of the Climate Change Convention, what is our position as regards adopting voluntary limits as a more advanced developed country?

    Encik Sidek bin Saniff: Sir, Singapore supports the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change. The Kyoto Protocol, under the Convention, called for the industrialised countries to limit their emission. This does not include the industrialising country. Singapore, being a

Column: 1352

developing country, will see its emission grow as it develops and industrialises further. So my Ministry is of the opinion that it is not appropriate for Singapore to address the issue on voluntary limits when we have not arrived.

MEDICAL REGISTRATION ACT

(Compulsory voting of election of Singapore Medical Council
members)


    2. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for Health if he will consider introducing legislation to amend the Medical Registration Act where the issue of a practising certificate and the compulsory voting at election of Singapore Medical Council members are coupled.

    The Senior Minister of State for Health (Dr Aline K. Wong) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, voting has been made compulsory at the elections of the Singapore Medical Council members under the Medical Registration Act 1997. This is because the Council, being the governing body of the medical practitioners, must represent the medical profession in Singapore. In the past, when voting was voluntary, only about 10% to 15% of the eligible doctors voted. Such a small turnout cannot represent the entire electorate among the medical profession.

    It has been made clear to all the doctors that those who are not able to vote with a valid reason need only to write in and inform the Council. The penalty for those who do not vote and who are unable to provide a valid reason is a fine of $500. I believe doctors are responsible professionals and we do not have to resort to imposing the penalty. In fact, during the recent election conducted from 28th October to 1st November 1998, more than 90% of the doctors voted. For those who did not vote, the main reason was that they were overseas. This is a valid reason and no further action will be taken against them.

    The Council will hold back the renewal of a doctor's practising certificate only when he does not vote without a valid reason and when he also fails to pay the penalty. There is no need to amend the Medical Registration Act on this matter.

Column: 1353



    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): May I ask the Senior Minister of State if it is not too severe to cut off the livelihood of doctors just because they do not participate in the voting for the few representatives to the Medical Council?

    Dr Aline Wong: As I have explained to the Member, if a doctor did not vote, but he had a valid reason for not voting, he would not be subject to a penalty. If he did not have a valid reason, but he paid the fine of $500, then no further action would be taken against him. In my view, I think this is very reasonable. As I said, the doctors are responsible professionals. I think most of them would want to exercise the right to vote.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask the Senior Minister of State if she would consider just meting out the monetary penalty alone being sufficient to compel all doctors to vote for the representatives to the Medical Council?

    Dr Aline Wong: I think the monetary penalty is not the point. The point is that doctors should take the responsibility to vote. If you say the $500 is too severe or too heavy, then I would have to ask you: what would be a sufficient amount of fine in order to ensure doctors would vote?

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, does the Senior Minister of State think that it is equitable to deregister a medical practitioner if he does not vote and refuse to pay up the fine? Is our professional practice based on whether or not the doctor is committed to vote in the future? And is this tantamount to saying that if a citizen refuses to vote or has no valid reason not to participate in the voting, he might lose his citizenship as well? It looks as if it is going to be the same case.

    Dr Aline Wong: Is it equitable? As I said, doctors in the past had felt that they needed to be represented adequately on the Medical Council and therefore they valued the vote. But the trouble is, in the past, when voting was not made compulsory, only 10% to 15% of them ever turned up to vote. In the end, they felt that the number of members elected did

Column: 1354

not represent them. So it is a chicken and egg question. So, we say, if you value the vote, you should all turn up to vote. And the way to make you come to vote is to tie that up with some penalty which is heavy enough that you feel there is a pinch. But the money is not the question. I must clarify that when a doctor fails to vote, his practising right is not revoked there and then. It is only when he renews his practising certificate, he may not be given the permission. So he can pay up the penalty.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, I have no quarrel with compulsory voting. My question is whether or not it is fair to link the voting to the renewal of certificate. Can a doctor practise without renewing his practising certificate?

    Dr Aline Wong: The linking of compulsory voting with the practising certificate is not limited to the medical profession alone. Even in health matters, for self-employed people, they are required to pay Medisave. If they do not pay up, then the renewal of their business licences could also be held up. So this rule is not peculiar to the medical profession.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is exactly what I am objecting. Why should we be linking everything to a penalty which would affect a person's livelihood and professional practice? Is it equitable in the first place?

    Dr Aline Wong: As I said, this is really an incentive for people to come and vote. So if the livelihood is so important to them, by all means pay the penalty if you cannot vote.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid this is only an administrative expediency. But the principle involved is whether it is equitable.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Senior Minister of State whether any attempt has been made to find out why doctors have failed to vote in the past? Has any study or census been taken? They

Column: 1355

may have very good reasons. Maybe they think that the Medical Council is not effective enough for them.

    Dr Aline Wong: Many of the doctors who failed to vote, when voting was not compulsory in the past, did so because they did not bother to.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Have you made any attempt to find out why they have not bothered? That is my question. Could you please try and answer the question?

    Dr Aline Wong: My answer is yes, of course, we have attempted to find out.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: This is becoming a fact of life in Singapore which is what we are against, and I support everything that has been said by my Party Member for Hougang.

    Mr Speaker: What is your question, Mr Jeyaretnam?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: The question is this: Singapore citizens seem to be living under one compulsion or another all their lives.

    Mr Speaker: What is the question?

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Is that desirable in a society where people should decide for themselves?

    Dr Aline Wong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not see the relevance of this to the question asked by Dr Lily Neo.

    Mr Simon Tay: The Senior Minister of State has my sympathies. I think the Medical Council has powers and therefore needs good officers and therefore responsible voting. May I ask the Senior Minister of State how many practitioners, in fact, have been knocked off and what serious obstacles, if any, are there to voting?

    Dr Aline Wong: This is the first time that we are exercising this Act which requires compulsory voting. During the exercise in October, out of a total of 4,866 doctors eligible to vote, 90.2% turned up to vote. The majority of the 477 doctors who did not turn up to vote were overseas. There

Column: 1356

were also some doctors on medical leave. Therefore, so far, nobody has been struck off the register.

TEST RUN OF ELECTRONIC ROAD PRICING SYSTEM

(Compensation to motorists charged accidentally)


    3. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Communications whether the Government has compensated those motorists who were charged accidentally in the test run of the Electronic Road Pricing System on 28th August 1998.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications (Dr Yaacob Ibrahim) (for the Minister for Communications): Sir, all of the 1,562 motorists, who were accidentally charged during the test run of the Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) gantries on 28th August 1998 have been sent a $10 CashCard.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, what is the rationale for refunding the affected motorists a flat rate of $10 CashCard which has incurred a Government expenditure of $15,620 rather than just paying them back the collected amount of $1,659?

    Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, on the morning of that particular day, we deducted between 50 cents and $3 accidentally from 1,562 motorists. We could have chosen to refund the exact amount. However, as a gesture of goodwill and to compensate for the inconvenience and the confusion caused, we have decided to give each of them a $10 CashCard.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, why did the Government give out goodwill? I would like to know who made the mistake and whether or not the taxpayers should bear the mistake of this goodwill, which was a mistake made by a civil servant.

    Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, we have conducted an internal inquiry into this incident and we have found that the party responsible is the ERP contractor and, as such, we would be claiming all costs incurred due to the incident from this ERP contractor. This would include the cost of the CashCard that we have sent out.

Column: 1357



    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, how did the LTA know who are the motorists who are overcharged and how were the CashCards sent to them? Were they sent to them or they came to collect them?

    Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, every in-vehicle unit (IU) has its own unit identity code which is indexed to the registration number of the vehicle. So when a vehicle with an IU passes under the ERP gantry, this unit identity code will form part of the normal ERP transaction. Usually, we will keep this ERP data for only 24 hours in order to allow LTA to settle with NETS. For that particular instance, we downloaded and retained the data for the express purpose of identifying the affected motorists so that the $10 CashCards could be sent to them.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, since the system is capable of capturing the identity of the car through the gantries, my question is whether or not this system itself is also capable of monitoring the movement of motorists and thus infringe the privacy of motorists?

    Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, as I have said earlier, we only retain the data for a maximum of 24 hours to allow us to settle the transaction with NETS. After that the data is deleted.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, is it possible to download the data and store it somewhere? Could you do that?

    Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: It is possible, but we do not do that.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Can the data not be downloaded and stored separately for future reference at all?

    Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: As I have said earlier, Sir, it is possible to download, but we do not do that except for those who have violated the ERP.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, the question is whether you do that or you do not do that. The system is capable of doing that if you want to. In other words, if the Government wants to monitor the movement of motorists, they could have done that.

Column: 1358



    Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, we do not do that, and the question is irrelevant.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, this is relevant. I believe the LTA has completed its investigation. Is the LTA confident that such errors will not occur again in the future? And what other systems are in place to make sure that the same mistake will not occur again?

    Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, the system that we have in place is extremely reliable. Any errors that have occurred during the test run have already been rectified. Nonetheless, we will be very vigilant to prevent any mishap that could happen, be it human or otherwise, and we will continue with our vigilance, as we do daily in Singapore.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, is the system capable of self-checking any errors that occur?

    Dr Yaacob Ibrahim: Sir, I do not have the exact answer. If the Member is interested, he could file a Question and I will answer at the next sitting.

CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT AND
ELECTRONIC ROAD PRICING CHARGES

(Payment by taxis)


    4. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Communications whether the policy of requiring taxis to pay Central Business District and Electronic Road Pricing charges defeats the Government's purpose for introducing such charges.

    The Minister of State for Communications (Dr John Chen Seow Phun) (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the primary objective of the Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) system is to bring about smooth traffic flow. With ERP, motorists are charged for their use of congested roads. This will make the cost of travelling more evident and encourage drivers to consciously plan their trips and consider alternative modes and times of travel. This is the rationale for the ERP system. This way, we can keep the crucial arterial roads and expressways relatively smooth flowing.

Column: 1359



    For road pricing to work, it must apply to all vehicles in order to be fair and effective and to keep road pricing charges to the minimum. Taxi drivers and commuters would then decide on the best route to take, as well as the basis of cost-sharing for road pricing, in order to enjoy the benefit of faster travel on the roads. To help taxis and commercial vehicles, I would like to inform the Member that the ERP charges are phased over three to four years.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: I am indebted to the Minister for his explanation. But the question still remains. As I understand the Minister, the purpose was to try and keep mainly users of private cars from roads which get congested in the mornings and evenings. But is it not the intention that they should switch to public service vehicles rather than use their cars, and are taxis not public service vehicles, no less than buses?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, it is true that we want to encourage commuters to take public transport and we have spent a lot of resources and efforts in promoting public transport. But we must also recognise that public transport vehicles do compete for road space and contribute to traffic congestion. As ERP is a traffic management tool, it is not appropriate to exempt them or reduce the ERP rates for taxis relative to other vehicles. In fact, the buses are also paying the ERP charges depending on the size of the bus. It has a pcu (passenger car unit) of two, so the bus is actually paying two times the charges compared to private cars. But of course, we are phasing in over four years. And bus is a more efficient transport. Therefore, the cost per commuter will actually be very, very small. For taxis, it is different. Taxis provide a point-to-point personalised form of transport service with comfort levels comparable to that of cars and occupy the same road space as cars. So taxi commuters would therefore pay the same ERP rates as if they were using their cars. Nonetheless, in recognition of the role of taxis as a form of public transport, albeit a

Column: 1360

personalised one, the full ERP charges for taxis will be phased in over three years to help taxi drivers and commuters to adjust.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Is it not the Ministry's intention then to force people who can afford to pay taxi fares to travel on buses?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: We will let the commuters decide what kind of service they want, what price they want to pay, and if you look at our public transport fares, whether it is MRT, bus or even taxis, and compare them to other countries, I think Singapore's public transport fares are very, very affordable.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: We get this answer every time, Mr Speaker, Sir. The prices in Singapore are very, very affordable. But does the Ministry realise that even a small payment can be a burden on families which cannot even find enough to live on?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: That is why we have a choice of a wide range of services and after all, Sir, I do not see the relevance of this question to the Question that he is asking about taxis.

CABLE TV NETWORK

(Progress of installation)


    5. Mr Harun A Ghani asked the Minister for Information and the Arts what is the progress of installing cable TV network in Singapore for public and private buildings and when the exercise will be completed.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Information and the Arts (Encik Yatiman Yusof) (for the Minister for Information and the Arts): Sir, as at 31st October 1998, the Singapore Cable Vision (SCV) has cabled up 90% of HDB flats, 57% of private high-rise and 33% of landed households in Singapore. This means that 82% of all households in Singapore have now been cabled up.

    The Singapore Cable Vision expects to complete the cable roll-out to all HDB, private high-rise and landed homes by September 1999.

Column: 1361



    Mr Harun A Ghani (Hong Kah): As 90% of HDB flats and 57% of private high-rise households have already been cabled up, when will cabling of Hong Kah or the Jurong area be completed?

    Encik Yatiman Yusof: The latest date for public housing to be fully cabled will be March 1999. For the benefit of the Member, Jurong will be fully cabled by March 1999. As for the other areas, Bukit Timah will be cabled in December this year; Jalan Besar and Bendemeer, by January next year; Yio Chu Kang and Tanjong Pagar by March next year.

GRANTING OF LICENCES TO INDIVIDUALS TO OPERATE TAXIS

(Government's policy)


    6. Mr Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Communications if he will outline the rationale for the Government's policy of not granting licences to individuals to operate taxis.

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun (for the Minister for Communications): Sir, prior to 1975, taxi licences were issued to individuals to operate taxis. However, this arrangement was unsatisfactory. Taxis were poorly maintained. There were malpractices and abuses. And some owners of taxi licences were not driving but hiring out their taxis to others and simply collecting rental. Worse, syndicates emerged to control and exploit taxi drivers. The result was unreliable and unsafe taxi services. Commuters suffered.

    To upgrade taxi services, we have since 1975 issued new taxi licences only to bona fide taxi companies or organisations which have the resources and expertise to manage the pool of drivers and fleet of taxis. As a result of this policy, today the three taxi companies, namely, Comfort, CityCab and TIBS, operate a combined fleet of 15,900 taxis. Commuters enjoy a wide range of services, including Premiere Taxi Service, Mercedes Cabs, London Cabs, Airport Direct and even Cab-Pooling services.

    Under the new policy, anyone can obtain a taxi driver vocational licence from LTA and rent a taxi from one of the taxi

Column: 1362

companies. Nobody, I repeat, nobody has been stopped from earning a living as a taxi driver.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: As I understand the Minister, there are two reasons underlying the Ministry's decision. One is that those to whom licences were issued, individuals, ie, to operate taxis, hire them out.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, can you proceed with your question? It is not necessary to repeat the answer.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Is that not what the companies are doing? They are hiring the taxis to the drivers. Yes. Are the drivers not paying a hiring charge to the companies? So what is the difference? The second is, the Minister says the Ministry found out a syndicate was controlling and exploiting the drivers. Would you rather have the companies exploit the drivers? May I ask: is one of the reasons for not granting licences to individuals to try and stop taxi drivers from expressing their opinion about the Government because I have been told more than once that one of the NTUC rules is that they should stop criticising the Government?

    Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Mr Speaker, Sir, the first question is about comparison between the syndicates and the public listed companies. There is no comparison. How can you compare them? The syndicates were out there to make profit and they did not care about the welfare of the drivers and the services that the commuters would get. It is precisely because of the experience that we have seen in the past that we have done away with individual licence as it will result in malpractices. But the companies are different. The companies today provide investments. For instance, they have spent a lot of money on the satellite system to enable radio booking and the taxi drivers actually receive the booking fee. Let me just give the Member an illustration of how taxi-drivers are being looked after by the companies. I take Comfort as an example. Today, Comfort has about 18,000 drivers, including relief

Column: 1363

drivers, and the average income of these drivers is about $1,800 per month. That means $32 million per month, and over a year it is $380 million. Do you know how much the company earns for its shareholders? $20 million over a year. That is about 7% of what the taxi-drivers are getting, not to mention all the services that they put in place to benefit the commuters and also the drivers, so that they can earn an easier living. Can a syndicate do such things? Obviously, it is out of the question.

    On his second question about taxi-drivers, they are responsible citizens. Of course, we have heard some of them, from personal experience, commenting on Government policies, but this is part and parcel of their right.

The coordinated efforts by the Government and the unions to explain the important need for immediate business cost reductions, the rationale behind the need for CPF and wage cost cuts and the prospect of massive job losses if these measures are not undertaken, have generally gone down well with the working populace. However, anxieties are still abound, especially the effect of these cost-cutting measures in the ability to continue servicing their mortgage loans. While the Government has said that it will help HDB dwellers, nothing appears to be in store for the lower middle income earners who, especially over the last two years, have upgraded to private properties. Some of them have lost their jobs as a result of the crisis.

    As an interim measure, I would like to propose that the Government consider the relaxation of CPF usage to allow for pooling of CPF resources among immediate family members to help those in trouble tide over their mortgage repayments during the crisis period. Working parents, children or siblings could assist the family member or members in trouble by temporarily allowing them usage of their CPF savings to pay for the monthly mortgage payments subject to certain regulations. Once the troubled family member becomes gainfully employed and overcomes his problem, the assistance should cease and the amount borrowed should be returned back progressively to the lenders.

    Savings in the Special Account of the CPF should also be temporarily freed up

Column: 1418

for such purposes and should similarly be returned upon employment stability and recovery of the economy.

    As a regulatory measure to assist troubled first-time private property purchasers, the Government, through perhaps the Monetary Authority of Singapore, could assist in pacing financial institutions involved in lending money for such purposes to help them reschedule loan repayments wherever feasible. HDB policy and guidelines employed to assist HDB flatowners could be used as a basis to regulate this.

    The Ministry of Manpower should also seriously consider the temporary reduction of the domestic worker levy. A reduction of 30-50% will go a long way in helping struggling dual income families affected by the CPF and wage cuts, but yet could not do away with the services of a maid to look after their children and/or aged.

    For businesses that are doing well and are benefiting positively from the cost reduction exercise, they should also shoulder some social responsibility in these tough economic times to correspondingly lower their product prices or service charges to help cushion the impact of wage cuts taken by the people. If the overall intention is to bring wages down to 1994 level, it is imperative that every constituent of the land, ie, the Government, the corporate citizens and the people, do their collective part to also bring down our cost of living as well as we can to 1994 standard. Only then will some form of equilibrium be achieved.

    Sir, in conclusion, allow me to applaud the CSC for their effort and boldness in making several important recommendations, both for the short and long term which, I believe, will have far-reaching implications for Singapore when implemented. Looking on the horizon, it is my hope to see the Government put in place a regular ongoing competitiveness monitoring and benchmarking mechanism to prevent us as far as possible from again being caught off guard. While it is fair to note that the currency crisis leading to significant

Column: 1419

depreciation of regional currencies, which is also a major cause of the erosion of our competitiveness was hard to predict, there were many tell tale signs pointing to the escalating cost of doing business in Singapore, which the Government and statutory boards have influence in moderating without having to undermine the free market mechanism. This includes, as I have mentioned earlier on, land pricing and rental regulations, a major business cost component, port, utilities and communication charges. Ways must also be found to further refine our flexible wage and compensation system to prevent the need for the CPF mechanism from being continually relied upon in the future to adjust cost and address competitiveness issues.

    The unusually long growth period in Asia, including here in Singapore, has made us forgotten that crises, bubbles and crashes are an inevitable part of economic business cycles. We should now brace ourselves to be better prepared for future ups and downs. Sir, having an efficient competitiveness barometer will go a long way in regularly checking where we stand in comparison to regional as well as industrialised and developed countries. Such indicators will enable prompt regulatory actions to be taken that will enable us to sustain our competitiveness on a real time basis and, hopefully, do away with the need for off-Budget measures and jolting the lives of Singaporeans with CPF and wage cuts. Such an approach will increase Singapore's and the business community's resilience in weathering the current and future storms.

    Sir, I support the motion.

    Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio): Mr Speaker, Sir, exceptional times require boldness of vision and action. It calls for a common understanding and purpose by the people to collectively meet the challenges. These are exceptional times. Since the release of the Report by the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness and the reconvened National Wages Council, I had met up with my

Column: 1420

grassroots leaders and residents. They expressed understanding and support of the two Reports.

    Let me make two general remarks before I comment on the measures proposed. In a crisis, we are pressured to find quick answers. Yet, in our evolving history, the present crisis will only be a blip. We must be careful not to pursue quick solutions inconsistent with sound principles, which underpin our long-term interests and survival. Short-term solutions must by its definition be exceptions that can be dismantled after the crisis. These solutions cannot and should not be allowed to adversely change the long-term course of the nation.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is one thing to accept the rationality and relevance of the recommendations themselves, and yet another the pains faced upon implementation. The people want and expect the Government and employers to convince and show openly that they understand and appreciate the pains suffered and sacrifices made by the people.

    I call upon our employers to declare that they will share fairly the profits in good times as they now desire workers to make sacrifices for the company. When the good times return, the cuts should not only be restored but profits be shared through bonus and other benefits.

    Let me now turn to the short-term specific measures to deal with the crisis. The need for short-term specific measures arises from our sudden loss of competitiveness. A major reason for this loss of competitiveness is the relative appreciation of the Singapore dollar to the currencies of our competitors. Some hence feel that allowing the Singapore dollar to depreciate is a less painful answer to cutting cost. It would be helpful for the Government to make more efforts to explain why cutting cost is the better alternative.

    Let me look at the short-term measures from both the company's viewpoint and the worker's viewpoint. I will start with the company. The cut in business cost is not only for external competition, but also internally to help our companies survive.

Column: 1421

There is thus strong support for the specific measures proposed by the Committee, particularly the following:

Foreign Worker Levy

    The foreign worker levy should be reduced. This will bring much relief to those companies with high dependence on such workers. These workers do not pay CPF and a cut in the latter does not lighten the cost burden. Affected sectors include the food and beverage, and construction. The amount of cut in the levy should provide as good a relief as the CPF cut.

Cut in Land/Factory Rent

    The rent of industrial land, factory and commercial properties should be further reduced. The proposal to return to the 1990 rent level is much welcomed. HDB and JTC, being the largest landlords of such properties, should take the lead. Private owners will follow. The short-term help is obvious. There is also a long-term impact as companies can remain in Singapore. Singapore will also be more attractive to foreign investors.

    HDB and JTC should also be more willing to rent out vacant land on TOL. I have been told that Singaporeans have been forced to go overseas to grow turf grass for import to Singapore even though vacant lands are available for this purpose here. It is also difficult and expensive to obtain the use of such land.

    There were also calls for the following:

Training Subsidies

    To encourage companies to train their workers, the subsidies given should be increased. This will encourage and make it easier for companies to retain the workers for retraining. Training fees should also be kept low. These fees have been escalating much too quickly.

Medisave Rate for the Self-Employed

    To assist the self-employed, the increase in the Medisave contribution planned for

Column: 1422

next year should be deferred. In fact, the Government should consider reducing it during this period of crisis.

Parking Charges

    Parking charges for commercial and heavy vehicles should be reduced.

Banking Charges

    The various banking charges like the opening of letters of credit should be reduced.

    Let me now turn to the workers. As wages form a large part of the cost to companies, cost cutting means cutting wages. This is painful for the people. Hence, at the same time, efforts must be made to provide relief to the people.

    Some of the reliefs that were sought include:

Housing Loans Repayment

    Help should be given for the repayment of housing loans. A major concern with the CPF cut is the worker's ability to finance the monthly repayment of his housing loan. As most people own HDB flats, I hope the Government will announce schemes to help owners of HDB flats. HDB has constantly assured flat owners that they will be assisted. They must continue to reassure the people. I am happy that several banks are also offering alternative repayment schemes to lower the monthly repayment.

    The recent decline in interest rates has helped to reduce the monthly instalments of housing loans substantially. But interest rates are capricious. We should not be lulled into complacency by this development. It is necessary to set in place schemes to help with the housing loan repayment.

Maid Levy

    The levy should be reduced. This will bring much relief to families who desperately need the assistance of maids such as families with very young children and old parents to look after and both spouses are working.

Column: 1423



Cut in Fees and Charges

    During this period, every bit of cut to the cost of living is a help to the people. There were calls for reduction in fees and charges and for increase in rebates:

    School fees at all levels from kindergarten to university be reduced.

    Utility charges including telephone charges be reduced.

    Transport charges like bus and taxi fares be reduced.

    Service and conservancy charges by Town Councils be reduced. Government should also give more service and conservancy rebates, especially to the lower income group. In this period of crisis, the rebate should be extended to 5-room and Executive flats.

    Government should give more income tax rebates.

    Medical charges should be reduced. The number of Class C beds should be increased.

    Companies and hawkers should reduce prices. Particular concerns were expressed for the low income group. Questions were asked if this group of people could be spared the cuts, or alternatively be provided with additional reliefs.

    Keen interests were expressed on the restoration of the wage and CPF cuts. Residents were keen to know when the cuts will be restored. They would like the NWC to review the situation regularly so that the cuts can be quickly restored when the crisis blows over.

    Now let me turn to the long-term measures to Singapore's competitiveness. While we seek to develop new strategies, it is important not to forget, but to renew and revitalise existing core strengths. Let me share the following:

Column: 1424



    We have enjoyed rapid growth for over 30 years. Parents who had gone through hard times try to make sure that their children are never in want of anything. This is understandable. But we also run the risk of our young not understanding poverty and what it means to be resilient.

    We need to always compete with the world for our existence. This requires hard work, commitment, a fighting spirit and constantly to remind our young of the need to be competitive. If we lack this motivation, we are doomed. After having it so good for so long, is our mental and physical capability still strong? We must stress national values and priorities.

    The regional countries have been ravaged by the economic storm. They are chastened. Their systems will now be leaner. We must take this opportunity to learn and emerge wiser from the crisis. We must remind our people that they cannot take things for granted, that our rosy future is not preordained. While we enjoy during the good times, we must also prepare for and set aside something for bad times. The future of Singapore is in our hands. We decide and make the future. If we learn this lesson and emerge from the crisis stronger as a people and a nation, the pains will not be in vain.

    Here, I would like to add a word of caution. As we plan for the future, we must not give the impression to the people that this will guarantee us against future economic difficulties. We must remind the people that whatever we do difficult moments can surface. There are too many factors and imponderables in the real world. What we can do and must do is to constantly anticipate and prepare for them. We must not be lulled into complacency.

    We must be better motivated and committed to our work and companies. Several employers told me that they have difficulties hiring people, or if they do manage to hire, some workers do not stay on long, even during this difficult period. Our workers are fussy. If the work is demanding, they do not stay long. They

Column: 1425

hop from one job to another for pay increases, even small amounts. They do not like to go for training. If they accept training, they are not happy with their bonds. Those who are trained often do not stay long, lured away by higher salary elsewhere, feeling no obligations to the companies which train them. I have personally encountered others who during this crisis would rather stay unemployed at home than to take up a lower paid job, or a job that is "too far" away from their home.

    We are indeed lucky to have painstakingly cultivated tripartism. We had shared both the bounty in good times and the privation during bad times. This has built trust, consensus and understanding among the Government, employers and employees. Many foreigners have expressed disbelief that our workers agreed to have their salaries cut. In some countries, the very suggestion itself will already cause an uproar. For this, we must indeed be proud as a nation. This is an element of long term strength and competitiveness. We must ensure that tripartism endures.

    While the present cost cutting proposals cut down the value of the resources, the actual resources used do not decrease. In view of the scarcity of many resources, we should make an effort to use less of them. We should call upon our people and companies to cut down waste by using these resources more efficiently. They must be constantly aware of the importance of conserving resources. If necessary, we should consider campaigns to remind and encourage people to use water and electricity more carefully, to be more productive in our work, to help keep our environment clean, to protect our facilities so that less maintenance and repair expenses are needed. This is an element of enduring competitiveness.

    To conclude, I call upon our people to stand united during this time of crisis, to make painful sacrifices for the nation. We must support the cost cutting measures to help our companies and hence ourselves to ride out the storm. This is in the interest of the nation and for the

Column: 1426

collective good. Meanwhile, the Government and employers must show understanding of the pains incurred and provide unstinting help to alleviate them.

    On a longer term, we must remember that vicissitudes are part and parcel of the economic life of a nation. We must remember this when the good times return. We must never take the good times for granted. We must always prepare for lean times in times of plenty.

    Our existing strategy has done us proud as we have braced the current crisis much better than our neighbours. We must forge an even more robust strategy and a national cohesiveness that will anchor the country against future uncertainties.

    On this note, Sir, I support the motion.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in full support of the motion by the Minister for Trade and Industry.

    Sir, there is wide consensus that the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness has carried out a comprehensive analysis and made well constructed recommendations. Many of my colleagues have dwelt at length on the strategic issues. So I will confine my comments to the short term measures.

    Feedback by the various industry groups that the GPC spoke to highlighted two observations. Firstly, there is a sense that many of the recommended interim measures are weighted towards manufacturing and construction. Secondly, sectors such as retail and food and beverage are worried that the proposed reduction in wages will dampen consumption, which will more than overwhelm the benefits from a reduction in operating costs.

    Generally, companies, especially the smaller operators in trading and services, are seeking help as they face a cash flow crunch in the short term and would like to better position themselves after the downturn.

    Sir, I would like now to propose specific recommendations to achieve the following two objectives:

Column: 1427



    Firstly, to help improve the cashflow for companies and, secondly, to mitigate against the inevitable dampening effect on consumption.

Improve cashflow for companies

    Thirdly, although various assistance schemes such as LEFS have been widened to benefit more companies, many non-manufacturing concerns, such as trading companies, still do not qualify. They seek the availability of some form of Government-assisted trade financing scheme to help offset reduced credit lines by banks.

    Fourthly, whilst many applaud the emphasis on training and upgrading, companies would like existing schemes to be more generously applied to executive, managerial and general training. This will allow for smoother progression into managerial roles within the same organisation or industry.

    Fifthly, most companies realise the importance of technology and are willing to invest in spite of the high capital costs. However, they usually find maintenance to be a very heavy burden to bear, especially during this period of slowing, if not contracting, revenues. Can the Minister for Finance consider allowing deductions for maintenance costs, for tax purposes?

Mitigate against dampening effect on consumption

    Sir, many of my colleagues have commented on the dampening effect on

Column: 1428

consumption of wage reduction. There is recognition by retailers that consumption is closely linked to disposable income, confidence and consumer psychology. As much as we can wish that the media would not be overly negative or pessimistic, I would like to suggest the following as well:

    Firstly, can some temporary relief be provided for individuals, for example, as has been raised by several Members, by reducing the foreign maid levy by, say, $100 per month, in response to the impending reduction in household income, but with the Ministry of Manpower still maintaining control administratively?

    Secondly, can the Minister for Finance consider granting a bigger personal tax rebate?

    Thirdly, can Electronic Road Pricing, especially into the Central Business District, be temporarily suspended on Saturdays to give the retail sector a boost?

    Sir, there has been a lot of debate over how much Government should bear, whether it should be an equal burden or in equitable proportions. Unlike other countries, we at least have the luxury of such a debate. It is a luxury that did not happen by accident, but one that has resulted from strong fundamentals and good Government. Although both arguments are equally compelling, I think we should refrain from distorting the cost structure too much in order to gain more moral authority. We all understand that wage and CPF cuts are hard to stomach, but we all recognise that unless companies can survive, jobs cannot be preserved.

    On that note, I would like to urge the Government to consider the additional recommendations outlined above and to implement the CSC proposals as soon as possible.

    Mr Gerard Ee (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Report of the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness is comprehensive. If only we had the benefit of the findings and recommendations two years ago. For a long time now we have heard grumbling about the high cost of

Column: 1429

operating in Singapore. I have often heard disbelief expressed over the BERI's Report. For a long time now employers have grumbled about rapidly rising labour costs unmatched by an increase in productivity, disloyalty of labour, poor attitudes of new entries to the labour market.

    In this current economic downturn, some employers have expressed their hope that people's expectations will be moderated, more realistic.

    The Committee has done an excellent job of identifying the issue and I am generally in agreement with its recommendations. My concern is with the details, the implementation of the recommendations that, if mishandled, can cause much pain without providing the cure. I share many of the areas brought up by earlier speakers and I shall not repeat them. I shall focus on a couple of areas that I feel have not been raised.

    We must realign our wage structure to be competitive. The question has been raised as to whether the targeted 15% cut in wage cost is enough. Concern has been raised on the impact of such a cut on the lower paid wage earners and there has been a call to make a bigger cut for higher wages to help the lower paid workers. I would like to caution that higher paid workers may not necessarily have such a large advantage over the lower paid workers. Many do not benefit from large housing subsidies or other subsidies. Many are heavily mortgaged on their home. These people will not have a benevolent Town Council with patience over late payments of conservancy charges. I fear that, without care, suspicion may arise that one party or the other is not bearing a fair share of the pain, and this will have an impact on social cohesion.

    Our enterprises will have to carry on the best they can. There will always be a need to supplement our workforce with skilled foreign workers. There is an urgent need to reduce the levy for skilled foreign workers substantially. I do, however, question the appropriateness of reducing the levy on unskilled foreign workers. We

Column: 1430

should not encourage the import of unskilled foreign workers. Jobs, usually filled by such workers, should be kept for Singaporean workers who, due to the lack of appropriate skills, have to be retrained and are temporarily requiring a job, any job, to survive. As for the foreign workers, we should require employers to hire from among the pool of retrenched foreign workers, instead of forcing them to be repatriated. Many of these foreign workers cannot and do not want to return home because of the heavy debt that they incur in getting to Singapore. It would be a humanitarian policy which will also help see the continuing need for foreign workers without resulting in an increase in their numbers.

    To help our enterprises seek new markets and establish offices overseas, we should set up Singapore Trade Centres in the cities where business opportunities exist. These centres should offer a one-stop business support service where Singapore businessmen can rent temporary office facilities at low cost and obtain help to transcend language and cultural barriers.

    In conclusion, I support the recommendations made by the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness. It is now essential to ensure proper implementation of the recommendations and to continue monitoring our competitiveness and fine-tune the system as Singapore regains its footing and get back on track for continuing economic growth.

    Dr Toh See Kiat (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, I applaud the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness (CSC) for its calls to cut wages, electricity and telecommunication charges, port service charges, extend property tax and income tax rebates, reduce income and road taxes, offer infrastructural support for working mothers who need child care facilities, adjust industrial land prices to international benchmarks, and adjust downwards the cost of owning cars through reducing customs and petrol duties.

    Sir, there are many "goodies" in the package for businesses, but I want to highlight the plight of the consumer and

Column: 1431

the help that we too sorely need. I ask the Government, in accepting the CSC's Report, to spare a thought for the consumers, please.

    Specifically, I have a few proposals, but I would not repeat the proposals like the maid levy and GST cut which my colleagues have raised in this House and which I fully support. First, I want to speak against the CSC's recommendation to reduce the $200 GST exemption for day trippers who have shopped overseas. Much as I wish Singaporeans would have a greater sense of dignity and solidarity in the face of abusive and hostile treatment from those they buy from, I realise that the savings are significant and there are some who need the savings badly enough to face shoddy treatment. Are we going to say that GST is being leaked there too and so retailers should be protected through the diligent collection of GST from such individuals? If so, I fear efforts in promoting e-commerce will be greatly hampered. If retailers are hurting from competition, whether from Johor, Batam or cyberspace - surely the answer is in themselves. I urge Government to further consider easing the burden of the average consumer by, for example, making sure that not only those who earn below $1,200 be spared the wage cut, but, in addition, Government should continue to give rebates for service and conservancy

Column: 1432

charges in respect of 1- to 3-room flat dwellers and town councils. As my colleague, Mr Gerard Ee, has mentioned, we should have the compassion to allow for those who have financial difficulties to pay their charges in instalments in easy payment schemes.

    The HDB also provides a benchmark for property prices, in that the price ceiling of the HDB market is a convenient base on which to prop up the floor of the private property market. With the distance between top end HDB flats and low end private flats as little as they are at present (and almost non-existent between the Executive Condominiums and entry level private condominiums) - surely the HDB could lower their sale prices. If this means a larger subsidy from the Government, is this not the right time to do it? Similarly, HDB mortgage rates could be lowered to provide flat owners some relief.     I turn now to businesses. Landlords, especially the GLCs, HDB and JTC, must reduce their rental; retailers must cut the prices of at least the basic necessities, as NTUC Fairprice has done; insurance companies must ease up on their collection of premiums or provide easy payment schemes, as NTUC Income has done; and professionals such as doctors and pharmacists must charge lower fees so healthcare becomes more affordable. Restaurant owners must take their heads out of the sand and work at charging less, and accept that they must not insist on a flat 10% service charge in all circumstances. If they could reduce their service charge to only 5%, I suspect the rise in clientele would more than make up for the loss!

    Nevertheless, I call on the Government to be easy on the SMEs who scramble to pay the Government charges, levies and CPF contributions on time - but fail. Column: 1433

the added burden of heavy penalties will drive the SMEs under and more people will lose their jobs.

    In the spirit of tripartism, cost cutting is not just for workers and Government. The employers who are business owners must also contribute their share. We have embarked on a campaign to identify cheap places and inform consumers on businesses which will give them value for money - whether they be hawker centres, shops, supermarkets, restaurants, or other businesses. We will be conducting seminars and printing booklets to educate and help consumers to stretch their dollar and to understand their rights when, for example, their hire purchase companies foreclose in on them. We will protect consumers and campaign to expose profiteers, opportunists, those identified with the help of our "eyes and ears" all over Singapore - our 600,000 members, union members and members of the public. We will publish the names of these institutions that do not charge the way that we advocate and we will channel more customers to those who are easy on the customers.

    We hope, of course, that the Government will show its concern for consumers and give us a grant to work on this project. CASE calls on all consumers to work with us to make our dollars go a long way through this dark storm ahead.

    Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Bukit Timah)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness has recently made two sets of recommendations. One is on how to deal with the current economic crisis, while the other is on how to prepare our economy to face the future challenges. In the short-term, our workers and the trade unions have to accept pay cuts to

Column: 1434

help the companies regain competitiveness and, in the process, to save our jobs. In the long term, we have to equip ourselves with new skills to operate in a knowledge-based economic environment. We, in the labour movement, support both sets of recommendations because we are convinced that they are in the best interests of our workers.

    During our debate in Parliament yesterday, I was surprised to hear one MP saying that the 15% wage cut is not enough. He suggested a 30% cut. The question is: during the last few months when we were debating on these issues, why did the employers and companies not put forward the reasons for the 30% wage cut? They should list out the cost structure in the various sectors in the business community to present their case. In fact, over the last few months, they have remained silent. So, after we have explained to our workers why we should agree to take a 15% wage cut, they accepted it. Now, the employers are saying that it is not enough. Furthermore, the said MP is a member of the National Wages Council (NWC) which recommended the 15% wage cut. Why is he now questioning the 15% cut? Since he sat in the NWC, he should be in the best position to know why the reduction should be 15%.

Here, I would like to thank our workers for being so understanding and for supporting this recommendation to reduce 15% of their employers' wage cost.

Do we have a social security net to meet their needs? When our workers are retrenched or have suffered a wage cut, do we have a social security net to help them?

    In some developed countries, the jobless can look to unemployment benefits. So some people are questioning why we do not have social security in

Column: 1435

Singapore. Does it mean that because we do not have unemployment benefits, we do not really have social security? Are they correct in their accusation? I do not think so. I do not think we should look at the issue so narrowly - that just because we do not provide unemployment benefits, there is no social security in Singapore.

    In fact, what are the basic needs of the people? First, jobs; second, housing; third, medical care; fourth, education. In fact, all of these have been provided for in our social system but very often we take them for granted, and we forget that they are part of our social security system.

    Take jobs, for example. We have made job creation our top priority. Over the years, we have brought in many foreign investments to Singapore. Many jobs have been created. Our preference is on quality investments because they are the ones that can afford to pay higher wages. Over the past 10 years, our real wages have gone up by an average of 5% per year. This is better than what has been secured even in many developed industrialised countries.

    Our philosophy is to train people for life-long employability. This is like teaching people to fish rather than merely giving them fish to eat.

    So, in this economic downturn, our top priority must be to find new jobs for the retrenched workers. A job with a steady income is anytime better than any form of unemployment benefit. The NTUC has joined hands with the Ministry of Manpower and the SNEF to develop a job bank to match those who are retrenched or unemployed with the vacancies available. At the moment, when we accept this 15% reduction in our total wage cost, we are appealing to the companies to retain the workers in this period of crisis, and retrench only as a last resort.

    In Singapore, housing is not a problem. We must thank HDB and its "Home Ownership" scheme. Since as many as 90% of our people own their own homes, even in this time of economic crisis,

Column: 1436

they do not have to worry that they may be thrown out of their homes by unscrupulous landlords when they default in paying their rents. But in many other countries, like Korea, for example, the workers live in quarters provided by their employers. The moment they lose their jobs, they lose their shelters over their heads too. In fact, in most developed countries, home ownership is about 60% (40% of them are living in rented properties). Once they lose their jobs, they will be thrown out of their house. So to them, unemployment benefit is of paramount importance. Despite that, in many of these so-called welfare states, many people are sleeping in the streets. In Singapore, our situation is different. We have different schemes to help our people. Therefore, I feel that our model is a better one.

Balance of cost cuts

    Three quarters of this cost saving package - $7.5 billion worth - comprises wage costs, through the CPF reduction and the NWC recommendations to reduce wages. In the public discussion of the CSC Report and also here over the last two days, the question has often been asked whether wages are bearing too large a share of the burden, and whether the Government can do more. Some have even suggested that the Government match the reduction in wage costs dollar for dollar.

    This is not possible. To understand why, we need to examine the composition of our GDP. We can think of GDP as the sum of all the incomes generated for the domestic production of goods and services. You add up all the money earned from productive effort and that is our output for the year. If you use this "income approach" to GDP, then you can divide GDP into three components:

    (1) Wages (including salaries and CPF) which make up 43% of GDP.

    (2) Indirect taxes (e.g. GST, ARF of cars) making up 10%.

    (3) The remaining 47% of the GDP is gross operating surplus, ie. earnings of companies and statutory boards, including depreciation. So wages, 43%; indirect taxes 10%; and the balance, gross operating surplus, 47%. So any cost reduction package will have to come out of either wages, indirect taxes, or essentially company earnings (companies meaning, including statutory boards).

    The economic crisis is already squeezing company earnings. Our aim is to help companies improve their bottom lines. Getting companies to bear a large share of this cost reduction would defeat this objective. So most of the cost reduction must come from the other two components of GDP, ie, wage costs and

Column: 1460

Government levies. Since total wage costs are much larger than Government charges, wages must inevitably account for a large part of the total cost reduction package.

    Of course companies doing well may pass on their cost savings to consumers, or invest them in business expansion or worker training. This includes, of course, statutory boards and Government-linked companies, such as JTC and Singapore Telecom. However, statutory boards and GLCs cannot simply run a deficit in order to give money away. Santa Claus has not come to town. They must operate as efficiently as possible so as to keep costs to a minimum. They also have a responsibility to operate commercially, just like any other company. Even hospitals must run efficiently and break even, given the cost recovery targets for the different classes.

    Once we deviate from this cardinal principle, and our statutory boards and GLCs ignore their bottom lines to operate contrary to commercial and economic logic, they will lose discipline, and become bloated and inefficient. Service will deteriorate. Eventually they must either go bankrupt and close down, or else the Government must bail them out, and raise taxes to pay for their deficits . This is exactly what has happened in many other countries.

    The $3 billion reduction in Government taxes and charges in this package is substantial, especially coming on top of the $2 billion announced in June, which was completely borne by the Government and which, judging by the debate over these last two days, has been largely forgotten. We already expect a budget deficit of 1% of GDP this year. Ministry of Finance estimates the deficit to grow to 3% to 4% of GDP next year. This is a sharp contrast from our usual surplus budgets.

    We are in a position to run this temporary deficit, only because we have been prudently maintaining budget surpluses and building up our reserves for many years. MPs and others have suggested that we should dip more deeply into the reserves, in order to minimise the hardship to Singaporeans. Some have

Column: 1461

    My reservation is not with the arithmetic, but the psychology. It is like high-living heirs who cannot wait to divide up their wealthy grandfather's estate. If we did this, we would change from being a nation of savers accumulating wealth to a nation of spenders depleting it.

    Poh Say Teck ( ) wrote a piece in the Lianhe Zaobao today, and as he said, this would send out all the wrong signals. First, that our situation is so grave that we have no choice but to use the reserves, and second, that we have a low threshold of pain, and cannot bear austerity and hardship. It is an excellent piece. It shows he understands, and there are Singaporeans who understand, and I commend it to you. His title is Zhen yao dong yong lao ben ma? [ ], loosely translated: "Do we really want to eat our seed corn?" So I asked Dr Ow Chin Hock, what does lao ben mean? He says it is very difficult to translate. It really means the money you keep for your old age. Some people call it guan cai ben [ ]. It is something you keep for a last resort, not spend at the first opportunity.

    This crisis is far from over. We must husband our reserves, because we cannot tell what the future may bring. We must not spend them at the first sign of trouble, to generate a false sense of prosperity and well-being. If we did, the reserves would soon be gone. And the next time we run into rough weather, which will happen sooner or later, we would have no more safety net, no more rabbits to pull out of the hat. We must therefore get back to prudent, balanced budgets as soon as possible.

    Singaporeans are worried about what is happening. They have followed events in the countries around us, and seen how these have affected us. They know retrenchments are higher, bonuses are smaller, and prospects are highly uncertain. They want to know what we can do to help ourselves. But to judge

These are substantial majorities, almost enough to cause the Opposition to lose their deposits.

Not only is our economy sounder, but the way Singaporeans have responded to this crisis has shown that we understand this problem, we know where our interests lie, and we are quietly working together to tackle this challenge.     This package will help to make Singapore companies, and the economy as a whole, more competitive, to reduce retrenchments and unemployment, to attract new investments and business, and to lay the basis for long term prosperity.
